results.headline: Young Love, the Unrequited Type

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of An Oversimplification of Her Beauty

results.summary_short: Terence Nance writes, directs and acts in “An Oversimplification of Her Beauty,” his film about the sweet romantic tension between two close friends.

results.headline: Sanitation Workers Get That Swing

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Trash Dance

results.summary_short: A choreographer finds the dance in the work of Austin, Tex., sanitation workers in a documentary by Andrew Garrison.

results.headline: Dreams Are Lost in the Melting Pot

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Reluctant Fundamentalist

results.summary_short: Mira Nair’s “Reluctant Fundamentalist” is an adaptation of a 2007 novel, in which a young Pakistani university lecturer reminiscences about his life in America.

results.headline: Dangerous Mission in Tight Quarters

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Numbers Station

results.summary_short: “The Numbers Station,” a spy drama starring John Cusack and Malin Akerman, unfolds in a concrete bunker.

results.headline: Coupling, Uncoupling, Dissembling, Recoupling

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Big Wedding

results.summary_short: A sex farce that centers on a wedding, with stars including Diane Keaton, Robert De Niro, Katherine Heigl and Susan Sarandon.

results.headline: Flying Machines and Gravity-Defying Kung Fu

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tai Chi Hero

results.summary_short: The future of Chen village is once again threatened in “Tai Chi Hero,” the second chapter in Stephen Fung’s lavish martial arts spectacle.

results.headline: Stripped of Clothes, Dignity and Maybe Shame

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Paradise: Love

results.summary_short: In “Paradise: Love,” a middle-age single mother in Austria treats herself to a birthday trip to a coastal resort in Kenya.

results.headline: A Stylistic Visit to Cocteau’s Oeuvre

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mortem

results.summary_short: The dark night of the blonde and the brunette in Eric Atlan’s “Mortem.”

results.headline: Birth of a Nation, in the Words of Salman Rushdie

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Midnight's Children

results.summary_short: Salman Rushdie is the narrator of his film adaptation of his novel, directed by Deepa Mehta.

results.headline: The Thick Have Their Needs, Too

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Pain & Gain

results.summary_short: Michael Bay’s “Pain & Gain,” a more modest venture than his usual blockbusters, chronicles the true-crime doings of three Miami personal trainers.

results.headline: How Do I Love Thee? Let Me Count the Weddings

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Married and Counting

results.summary_short: Allan Piper’s documentary “Married and Counting” follows two gay New Yorkers having wedding ceremonies in every state that allows marriage equality.

results.headline: Ja, That Manly Raft Trip, Blond Manes a-Whipping

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kon-Tiki

results.summary_short: “Kon-Tiki” dramatizes Thor Heyerdahl’s celebrated 1947 trip across the Pacific aboard a wooden raft.

results.headline: Kindred Souls, Whoever They Are

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Arthur Newman

results.summary_short: In “Arthur Newman,” a bored middle-aged man and a young thief become road trip companions.

results.headline: Luminous Time Capsule, Bobbing Alongside the Present
results.display_title: Out-Takes From the Life of a Happy Man

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Out-Takes From the Life of a Happy Man

results.summary_short: In “Out-Takes From the Life of a Happy Man,” the director Jonas Mekas, now 90, splices together luminous moments that he filmed in the past.

results.headline: A Heartland Without Soul

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of At Any Price

results.summary_short: “At Any Price” is a critical exploration of modern agribusiness and its cutthroat ways, but it is also an allegory of American hubris in the 21st century.

results.headline: Back in Salem, Mass., This Time It’s Music That Casts a Spell

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Lords of Salem

results.summary_short: “The Lords of Salem,” by Rob Zombie, is an updated version of the witchcraft for which the town is famous.

results.headline: A T-Shirt War in Small-Town Wisconsin

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Oconomowoc

results.summary_short: “Oconomowoc,” set in rural Wisconsin, is a paean to aimlessness, written and directed by Andy Gillies.

results.headline: After the Apocalypse, Things Go Downhill

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Oblivion

results.summary_short: In “Oblivion,” Tom Cruise is a repairman on a post-apocalyptic Earth who finds himself confronting a stranger-than-usual work order.

results.headline: Reality and Fantasy: Desire Blurs the Line

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of In the House

results.summary_short: François Ozon’s new film, “In the House,” stars Fabrice Luchini as a high school teacher obsessed with his student’s writing assignments.

results.headline: Keeping His Secrets Well Up His Sleeve
results.display_title: Deceptive Practices: The Mysteries and Mentors of Ricky Jay

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Deceptive Practices: The Mysteries and Mentors of Ricky Jay

results.summary_short: The documentary “Deceptive Practice: The Mysteries and Mentors of Ricky Jay” invites viewers to join one of Mr. Jay’s magical mystery tours. But don’t expect him to reveal where that coin went.
